97f98e5df342.description: Perspectives of a 2x entrepreneur turned VC at @UpfrontVC, the largest and most active early-stage fund in Southern California. Snapchat: msuster
97f98e5df342.name: Both Sides of the Table
97f98e5df342.shortDescription: Perspectives of a 2x entrepreneur turned VC at @UpfrontVC…

paragraphs.text: I was always fond of saying about fund raising, “When the hor d’oeuvres tray is passed take two and put one in your pocket for later. Just don’t take the whole tray.” My analogy was that there are markets where it’s relatively easier to raise capital and therefore you should take a little bit more but you should create a budget where you only spend 70% of what you raise on a pace of 18 months.
paragraphs.name: 89a0

paragraphs.text: Great post, couldn’t agree more. It’s a trade off short-term vs long-term, and unique to every startup. The entrepreneur’s funding ask also provides further insight regarding his or her approach to building the business, beyond the qualitative aspects of the pitch.
paragraphs.name: a2b1

virtuals.subtitle: Adding to point #3: how much capital is actually needed to grow sufficiently, to hit the milestones and help ensure an up round.

content.subtitle: Adding to point #3: how much capital is actually needed to grow sufficiently, to hit the milestones and help ensure an up round.

b13382ec16e0.title: One other thing that jumped to mind (to play devil’s advocate) — I recently read one of Jason…

paragraphs.text: One other thing that jumped to mind (to play devil’s advocate) — I recently read one of Jason Lemkin’s biggest learning lessons was not accepting as much money as he could have, resulting in him having to go back to the VC for another check (no bueno). I don’t think he meant raise/accept as much as you can possibly raise, but rather don’t be too conservative either.
paragraphs.name: 4f89

251f2609c6d.title: Spot on. Need to build a lot of this (especially the 70% over 18 months rule) into thinking for my…

paragraphs.text: Spot on. Need to build a lot of this (especially the 70% over 18 months rule) into thinking for my company right now as we embark on a raise. Thank you Mark, as always, fantastic advice.
paragraphs.name: bff9

1393b3135392.title: So true. I have done both.

paragraphs.text: So true. I have done both. Having money allows you to make stupid mistakes just because you have the money. An exercise I have run dozens of times with my team is to ask, “If money were no object, what would we do?” Then I ask, “Since money is an object, how do we do those things even without the money?” So many ways to be creative when you HAVE to do it on the cheap!
paragraphs.name: 0bf5

f3918ae71fd3.title: “No matter how much you raise at your company you’ll end up spending it in 12–24 months”

paragraphs.text: “No matter how much you raise at your company you’ll end up spending it in 12–24 months”

paragraphs.text: I have been saying this for years. I am not on both sides of the table just the entrepreneur, but this post is spot on and somebody is going to say you are posting this just to lower valuations.

paragraphs.text: I understand the 20–25% thing for investors, but it’s the only piece that flies in face of raising less money… If investors see the opportunity as large, why isn’t 10% enough?

d5294ac987a0.title: Thanks for the insights as always Mark Suster!

paragraphs.text: Thanks for the insights as always Mark Suster! On your 2nd point, what should a founder’s mental position be when raising with capped convertible notes? Notes sorta forces their hand at grabbing for a higher valuation because they’re stuck in “rat shit.”
paragraphs.name: cc54

576a8073d2a.title: Thank you Mark for the eye opening post.

paragraphs.text: Thank you Mark for the eye opening post. We got similar feedback from our early investors and we also had the same thoughts when we began fund raising and we reached the same conclusions (both for the 70% and the amount of valuation). Now this was like a confirmation of our thoughts. I think it is a delicate balance between profit and where you want to be in a few months.
paragraphs.name: ab6b

paragraphs.text: So investors who don’t insist on 25% get to invest at a lower valuation in a company that is better aligned for success?

paragraphs.text: This is a great article and very informative. But It is way out of my league. I was only trying to raise a total of $150,000 and even with that, I was asked why I needed “so much money”. I wrote the article linked to below out of frustration, nevertheless, my points are valid.
paragraphs.name: d04e

paragraphs.text: Great insights! Have money - will spend, it must be part of our DNA. I also think you can learn alot from having to be scrappy due to tight funding. It prompts creativity and can a real motivator! I’m sharing this with our team as we build out our MVP.
paragraphs.name: bef4

51adbe769b05.title: Bang on! In today’s time of over cautious investments, down rounds are a given if earlier valuation…

paragraphs.text: Bang on! In today’s time of over cautious investments, down rounds are a given if earlier valuation was too high.
paragraphs.name: 59fa

paragraphs.text: As they say — “Too much money makes you numb & dumb” you loose the agility as well as creativity for putting the right product to solve a problem.
paragraphs.name: e342

paragraphs.text: Great post! I experienced first hand a startup get greedy and raise (no pun intended) a lot more money than needed, and they spent it just as fast trying to “scale.” The end result was over hiring resulting in layoffs, and a post money valuation that will make it extremely difficult to raise another round at a higher valuation.
paragraphs.name: 8e2d

paragraphs.text: https://bothsidesofthetable.com/what-is-the-right-amount-of-money-to-raise-at-a-startup-495931573c96#.tqwi286tu
paragraphs.name: e622

paragraphs.text: 2010: “TAKE THE MONEY”
paragraphs.name: a059

paragraphs.text: 2016: “Constraints can spark creativity”
paragraphs.name: d378

paragraphs.text: What changed in 6 six years?
paragraphs.name: b2e0

paragraphs.text: Given that .05% of all startups raise VC funds, and less than 1% of all startups raise Angel funds, I threw up in my mouth a little bit when reading the headline. It may be true that some startups face this hurdle, but the vast majority of founders scrambling for funding would gratefully face the challenge of raising TOO much money.
paragraphs.name: adc9

paragraphs.text: What a great read. Damn. It’s posts like these (and many others) that are guiding posts to my mental framework as an entrepreneur. I’ve taken the 18 months+ and only spending 70% very seriously (on top of finding talent /shipping under constraints etc). It gives us the space to really nail our market early and force creativity. Sometimes I think my startup runs in parallel with your blog Mark. It’s uncanny.
